reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I’ve spent over sixty years sticking to businesses I understand—consumer staples, insurance, railroads, simple banking. Tesla is a high-tech automaker with proprietary battery chemistry, software-driven autonomy, and an ever-evolving regulatory environment. Frankly, I can’t get comfortable with the inner workings of its technology or the pace of change. 2. Competitive Moat: Elon Musk’s brand has firepower, but in my view Tesla’s moat is narrow. EV competitors are lining up, legacy automakers have deep pockets, and battery breakthroughs can come from any corner. A brand alone isn’t a lasting castle. 3. Management & Capital Allocation: Musk is a visionary showman, but his approach to capital—levering up for new factories and watchdog headlines—feels more like a roller coaster than the steady hand I look for. He’s smart, but I haven’t seen the sort of disciplined, owner-like approach I’ve praised in people such as Ajit Jain at GEICO. 4. Financial Health & Consistency: Tesla’s recent profits are encouraging, but they’re built on massive capex and questions remain on margins once price cuts and competition bite. I prefer companies with long, unbroken records of free cash flow like See’s Candies or Coca-Cola. 5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: With no reliable intrinsic valuation from the data provided and a sky-high P/E, there’s no margin of safety here. I never buy a wonderful company at a head-scratching price. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Electric vehicles will matter for decades, but Tesla faces execution risk, regulatory scrutiny, and technological arms races. It’s like betting on the fastest horse in a race where half the field can learn to run overnight. 7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d rather own more shares of Coke, Procter & Gamble, or BNSF—businesses I know inside out, with durable moats and simple economics. In my world, absence of understanding is the greatest risk of all. Therefore, I’ll pass on Tesla.
